title: 47 U.S.C. § 230 - Communications Decency Act
content:
# Section 230 of the Communications Decency Act (1996)

## Full Legal Citation
47 U.S.C. § 230 (codified section of Communications Decency Act)

## Core Provisions

### § 230(a) - Findings and Policy
The Internet should be maintained and developed as a forum for free and open speech and commerce.

Platforms should be treated differently from traditional publishers to promote content creation and user freedom.

### § 230(c)(1) - Publisher Immunity
"No provider or user of an interactive computer service shall be treated as the publisher or speaker of any information provided by another information content provider."

**Implication**: Platforms are NOT liable for user-generated content like defamation, harassment, or other harms caused by third parties' posts.

**Scope**: Applies to any "interactive computer service" (social media, forums, comment sections, apps)

**Exception**: Does not apply if the platform created or developed the content ("information content provider")

### § 230(c)(2) - Good Faith Moderation Immunity
Platforms are NOT liable for "good faith" actions to:
- Remove or restrict "objectionable" content
- Disable access to content considered obscene, lewd, filthy, indecent
- Promote violence or illegal activity
- Violate platform terms of service

**Key**: "Good faith" is broadly interpreted; platforms have wide discretion

**Outcome**: Platforms can:
- Delete posts
- Ban users
- Demotion algorithms
- Content moderation without losing immunity

## Who It Applies To

### Interactive Computer Services (ICS)
- Social media platforms (Facebook, X/Twitter, Reddit, TikTok)
- Video sites (YouTube, Vimeo)
- Forums and comment sections
- Marketplace platforms (Yelp, Amazon reviews)
- Email services
- Mobile apps

### Who It Does NOT Apply To
- Traditional publishers (newspapers, magazines) for their own content
- Platforms that materially contribute to creating/developing illegal content
- Platforms knowingly promoting crimes (e.g., facilitating sex trafficking per FOSTA-SESTA 2018)

## Notable Exceptions and Carve-Outs

### FOSTA-SESTA (2018)
Removed immunity for sex trafficking facilitation
- Platforms liable if they "knowingly facilitate" trafficking
- State laws can impose liability for online sexual exploitation

### Intellectual Property
No immunity for copyright/trademark violations

### Federal Criminal Law
No immunity for crimes with specific victim connections

## Supreme Court Interpretation

### Zeran v. AOL (1997, 4th Circuit)
- Foundational case establishing broad immunity
- No liability for third-party posted content
- No duty to monitor or screen user posts

### Fair Housing Council v. Roommates.com (2008)
- Partial immunity: Liable for actively soliciting illegal content
- But neutral platforms mostly protected

### Gonzalez v. Google & Twitter v. Taamneh (2023)
- Supreme Court upheld immunity for algorithmic recommendations
- Even recommendations of terrorist content protected
- Broad reading of Section 230

### NetChoice v. Paxton & Moody v. NetChoice (2024)
- Struck down Texas and Florida laws mandating content neutrality
- First Amendment protects platforms' moderation decisions
- State cannot force platforms to host speech

## Current Debates

### Reform Proposals
- EARN IT Act: Carve-out for child exploitation (stalled)
- Kids Online Safety Act (KOSA): Moderation mandates for minors (pending)
- Algorithm transparency requirements
- Repeal/amend for specific categories (bipartisan proposals)

### Criticism
- Pro: Fosters free speech and innovation; enables user-driven platforms
- Con: Called a "get out of jail free card"; enables misinformation, extremism, harassment

## 2024 Status
Section 230 remains robustly intact despite challenges. Courts have consistently upheld broad immunity.
